; Thu, 05 Oct 2023 02:52:01 +0800 Julia Ormond sues Disney and CAA over alleged Harvey Weinstein assaulthttps://www.theguardian.com/film/2023/oct/04/julia-ormond-harvey-weinstein-lawsuit-disney-caa-new-york
;;2023-10-04T17:59:43Z;
;
;;2017 年的朱莉娅·奥蒙德。
;

;英国演员朱莉娅·奥蒙德因电影（如《秋季传奇》、《初夜》和《龙凤配》在一项诉讼中指控哈维·韦恩斯坦性侵，该诉讼还涉及创意艺术家经纪公司 (CAA)、华特迪士尼公司和米拉麦克斯。

;
;

;;相关：;;#MeToo 已经人们在权力的走廊里瑟瑟发抖。这是值得庆祝的事情|波莉·汤因比（Polly Toynbee）;

;
;

;周三向纽约最高法院提起诉讼，首先由 ;综艺;，奥蒙德声称这位名誉扫地的电影制片人在 1995 年 12 月的一次商务晚宴后对她进行了性侵犯，当时他引诱她进入给他按摩，爬到她身上，自慰并强迫她给他口交。

;

;奥蒙德在诉讼中声称，她向当时的经纪人布莱恩·洛德和凯文·胡瓦内讲述了韦恩斯坦的性侵犯事件。 ，并且 CAA 特工警告她不要说出来。卢尔德和胡瓦内（好莱坞重量级经纪公司之一 CAA 的现任联合主席）在诉讼中多次被提及为奥蒙德的代理人，但并未亲自将其列为被告；奥蒙德正在起诉 CAA 疏忽和违反信托义务。

;

;尽管自《纽约时报》和《纽约客》于 2017 年首次发表对韦恩斯坦掠夺性行为的调查以来，韦恩斯坦已在多起诉讼中被点名，但这种情况很少见。一场诉讼，指控韦恩斯坦的商业伙伴涉嫌为他提供帮助。这位 71 岁的前电影制片人目前因性侵犯被判 23 年徒刑，在纽约服刑，并于 2 月份被判;在洛杉矶被判处; 16 年以上徒刑。< /p>;

;奥蒙德的诉讼还指控韦恩斯坦与兄弟鲍勃创立的米拉麦克斯公司以及在 20 世纪 90 年代拥有米拉麦克斯的迪士尼公司监管和保留疏忽。该诉讼援引了米拉麦克斯和迪士尼的众多前高管，包括迪士尼前首席执行官迈克尔·艾斯纳和前董事长杰弗里·卡森伯格；被告也不是。

;

;在接受 Variety 采访时，奥蒙德表示，她发声是为了煽动好莱坞的系统性变革。 “我现在公开讲述我的故事，因为我觉得我们仍然需要系统性变革，而且我觉得我们需要推动者的问责，才能实现这一目标，”她说。 “我觉得这就是发生在我身上的事情。”

;

;“显然，哈维·韦恩斯坦已经入狱，而且将会在监狱里待很长时间，”她补充道。 “我个人认为，如果没有推动者，哈维不可能做到这一点。对我来说，就根本原因而言，这就是你必须深入了解的层面。”

; ;

;奥蒙德根据《成人幸存者法案》提起诉讼，该法案新继 #MeToo 运动之后，约克于 2022 年;通过;。该措施为年满 18 岁的性侵犯幸存者提供了一年的回溯期，无论性侵犯何时发生，他们都可以起诉施暴者。

;

;在涉嫌性侵犯时1995年12月，奥蒙德的事业蒸蒸日上——她在《秋日传奇》等热门影片中担任女主角，与布拉德·皮特和安东尼·霍普金斯演对手戏，并与理查·基尔和肖恩·康纳利共同主演了《第一骑士》。她于 1995 年与韦恩斯坦达成了制作协议。据称的袭击发生在一次晚餐后，奥蒙德和韦恩斯坦本应讨论他们的业务问题。

;

;该诉讼声称迪士尼本可以阻止这次袭击，米拉麦克斯和 CAA，这对她的职业和人际关系造成了“灾难性”损害。该诉讼指出，在袭击发生后的几年里，她“几乎从公众视野中消失”。

;

;奥蒙德告诉 Variety，朋友们多年来一直在关注她，记者经常问她：“发生了什么？对你来说？”

;

;“我不认为这件事发生是因为人们希望它发生。但无论如何，事情还是发生了。而且这种情况并没有停止，”她说。 “应该有适当的结构。”

;

;奥蒙德的律师在一份声明中表示，他们期待着客户出庭的日子。

;

;“我们的客户在个人和社会上都遭受了巨大的痛苦。道格拉斯·H·维格多（Douglas H Wigdor）和埃菲·布拉斯伯格（Effie Blassberger）告诉《综艺》杂志，“由于哈维·韦恩斯坦（Harvey Weinstein）的袭击，以及迪士尼、米拉麦克斯和 CAA 未能阻止这一事件，也未能在她报告所发生的事情后做出适当回应。” “她觉得 CAA 完全背叛了她，因为 CAA 明知无视她的安全和福祉，她期待追究那些促成哈维·韦恩斯坦可怕和掠夺性行为的人和机构的责任。”

;

;“CAA、米拉麦克斯在奥蒙德被哈维·韦恩斯坦袭击并随后被好莱坞抛弃后的许多年里，迪士尼继续从与哈维·韦恩斯坦的密切关系中获得丰厚的利润。”诉讼称。 “但对奥蒙德以及哈维·韦恩斯坦强奸、袭击和骚扰的许多其他女性所造成的损害尚未得到充分了解。”

; Thu, 05 Oct 2023 02:52:01 +0800 South American monsoon heading towards ‘tipping point’ likely to cause Amazon diebackhttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/oct/04/south-american-monsoon-heading-towards-tipping-point-likely-to-cause-amazon-dieback
;;2023-10-04T18:00:01Z;
;
;;一艘拖船和一艘渡轮搁浅在该市亚马逊河流域严重干旱形成的沙洲上巴西伊兰杜巴
;

;南美季风决定了该大陆大部分地区的气候，根据一项将区域降雨与亚马逊森林砍伐和全球砍伐联系起来的研究，该季风正被推向“关键的不稳定点”。报告的作者表示，他们发现自己的结果“令人震惊”，并敦促政策制定者立即采取行动，防止出现临界点，这可能导致降雨量减少 30%，并导致干旱枯死。森林和粮食生产的严重影响。

;

;该研究于周三;发布;在《科学进展》中，研究了森林退化和季风环流如何相互关联。

;

;利用过去的观测和计算机模型，发现亚马逊和南美季风是“一个耦合系统”，其中蒸散量热带雨林回收来自大西洋的水分，使其能够向南穿过整个大陆。

;

;人类通过土地清理、火灾、伐木和采矿而导致的亚马逊雨林退化，正在将该系统推向临界点，之后干燥的条件预计将导致雨林突然发生“政权转变”，雨林将无法维持自身并输送水分。

;

;该地区的其他生物群落也将受到影响，以及由于季风从亚马逊河向南延伸数千英里到达普拉塔河（;拉普拉塔河;）盆地，因此造成了大片农田的破坏。还会产生气候影响，因为受影响最严重的亚马逊地区历来都是重要的碳汇，尽管本周的另一项研究表明;它现在已经退化;，最多只能达到碳中和。森林枯死会释放大量的碳。

;

;亚马逊季风论文的研究人员看到了临界点的几个先兆，包括许多地区的降雨量下降、亚马逊旱季的稳步延长，土壤湿度减少，干旱频率和强度增加。据统计，在十年内就发生了三起百年一遇的干旱。

;

;“看到这些不稳定的迹象令人震惊，”该研究的主要作者尼尔斯·博乔 (Nils Bochow) 说道。特罗姆瑟大学和波茨坦气候影响研究所。 “但我们不应该失去希望。我们仍然可以行动。我们需要对雨林制定更严格的规定。”

;

;全球变暖加剧了森林的压力。他们的论文中没有包含今年的剧烈旱季，因为今年的旱季才刚刚发生，在此期间，许多亚马逊河流的水位远低于一年中这个时候的平均水平，导致航行问题、水资源短缺和;海豚和鱼类的大规模死亡;。

;

;之前的研究表明，当亚马逊地区 20% 到 30% 的森林被清理时，可能会达到一个临界点，尽管这个临界点到底在哪里还存在很大的不确定性。目前，17% 到 26% 的雨林已被破坏，至少已经退化。

;

;该论文没有给出临界点何时发生的预测，尽管其作者表示他们的预测研究结果证实了这种临界点比其他可能的气候临界点（例如格陵兰冰盖崩塌）更接近的风险和可能性。

;
;

;;相关：;;亚马逊海豚大规模死亡引发对脆弱物种的担忧;

;
;

;尽管自巴西中左翼总统路易斯·伊纳西奥·卢拉·达席尔瓦年初上台以来，巴西亚马逊地区的森林砍伐已经减少了一半，森林继续萎缩。在玻利维亚，损失正在加速。

;

;慕尼黑工业大学和波茨坦研究所地球系统建模教授尼克拉斯·博尔斯 (Niklas Boers) 将亚马逊耦合季风系统比作一把进一步倾斜的椅子，甚至连一阵风都能把它吹倒。

;

;“我的情绪反应是愤怒，”布尔斯说。 “随着每平方公里的森林砍伐，全球变暖的每一分之一度，我们都在增加临界点的风险。然而，停止砍伐森林却非常简单。这是一个绝对独特的生态系统，我们真的不能失去。”

;

;亚马逊专家、利兹大学环境科学教授 Dominick Spracklen 在评论该论文时表示，这项研究令人担忧。 “这种向干燥气候的迅速转变将对生活在亚马逊流域的人们产生灾难性的影响，”他写道。 “这项研究强调，亚马逊流域人民迫切需要共同努力，找到减少森林砍伐、防止森林进一步丧失并开始恢复近年来失去的地区的方法。”

; Thu, 05 Oct 2023 02:22:01 +0800 Gaza Strip protesters received bullet wounds to ankles, medics reporthttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/04/gaza-strip-protesters-received-bullet-wounds-to-ankles-medics-report
;;2023-10-04T18:04:03Z;
;
;;2023 年 9 月 27 日，以色列军队干预加沙地带的巴勒斯坦示威活动。
;

;医务人员据加沙地带的报告，在最近被封锁的巴勒斯坦飞地的动荡边界发生的骚乱中，大量抗议者似乎被故意瞄准脚踝。

;

;至少一人死亡，数十人死亡自九月中旬开始，一群年轻人举行示威活动（其中一些人投掷石块和燃烧瓶）以来，受伤人数更多。

;
;

;;相关：;;“艺术是我感受自由的方式”：在加沙围困下工作的艺术家;< /p>;

;

;这些抗议活动表面上是为了回应犹太团体对耶路撒冷敏感的阿克萨大院的访问增加，以及以色列国防军（IDF）针对被占领约旦河西岸的巴勒斯坦武装组织正在进行的袭击以及以色列和埃及对加沙的围困造成的经济苦难，目前已进入第 16 个年头。

;

;加沙地带恢复了不安的平静，工人进入以色列的过境点于 9 月 29 日重新开放联合国、埃及和卡塔尔的调解努力。自 2007 年以来控制该地区的伊斯兰激进组织哈马斯发言人哈齐姆·卡塞姆 (Hazem Qasem) 告诉《卫报》，“加沙人民希望生活在和平与尊严中。如果不满足我们的条件，可能会发生进一步的骚乱。”

;

;北部城镇拜特拉希亚的阿尔阿瓦达医院收治了七名患者，他们仍在接受脚踝枪伤的治疗，这是吉恩博士认为的一个关节无国界医生组织 (MSF) 在加沙的医疗活动经理皮埃尔表示，治疗起来极其困难。

;

;“它比腿部的任何其他部位都更难治疗，因为它是一个关节，有重量，”他说。 “它涉及一种称为‘游离皮瓣’手术的复杂移植物，并不总是意味着患者能够行走。如果失败，往往需要截肢。

;

;“加沙只有两名医生可以做到这一点，而且他们没有进行复杂血管修复所需的显微设备。”

; <图数据- media-id="c8aa4d41c80076e8accb7902595b68156cd113a6">; ; ; ;

;人权组织表示，此类瞄准程序是非法的，因为它们允许使用可能致命的武器以色列国防军在一份声明中表示：“过去几周，哈马斯恐怖组织沿着边境围栏组织暴力骚乱，目的是伤害以色列人。”安全部队……应该指出的是，以色列国防军只有在用尽所有可用选项后，并且只有在处理迫在眉睫的威胁时才采取实弹射击。”

;
;

;;相关：; ;'一个隐藏的宇宙”：巴勒斯坦儿童被送进监狱;

;
;

;最新的暴力事件与2018年开始、持续近两年的“回归大游行”抗议活动相呼应，其中227巴勒斯坦人在隔离栅栏每周举行的示威活动中被杀。抗议活动是由唐纳德·特朗普决定承认有争议的耶路撒冷市为以色列首都而引发的。

;

;数千人受伤，其中约 60% ;腿部被狙击手击中; - 入院人数已经超出了;摇摇欲坠的医疗部门。;

;

;从那时起，使用拐杖的截肢者已成为一种普遍现象飞地街道上的景象。作为回应，无国界医生为该地带的居民资助了一个新的假肢诊所，并在 al-Awda 医院设立了一个肢体重建中心。

;

;“很遗憾，我们已经成为这项工作的专家，”拉米说Abu Jasser，该中心的主管之一。 “我们现在拥有比 2018 年更好的设施和设备，我们可以进行大多数骨科和整形手术。但我们一天仍然只能治疗少数人。”

;

;其中一名受伤的抗议者名叫哈立德，他的双脚踝均被一颗子弹射穿。医生说，他康复得很好，但几个月后才知道他是否能够再次行走。

;

;“我在回归的三月里受伤了五次，”这位 26 岁的老说着，拉起短裤，露出膝盖周围的伤疤。 “我的大腿里、臀部里，我的头上都有弹片。”

;

; Thu, 05 Oct 2023 00:22:01 +0800 Azerbaijan’s president snubs EU-hosted talks on Nagorno-Karabakhhttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/oct/04/azerbaijan-president-snubs-eu-hosted-talks-on-nagorno-karabakh
;;2023-10-04T15:14:29Z;
;
;;Aliyev
;

;Azerbaijan will not attend an EU-brokered event in Spain where its president, Ilham Aliyev, was set to hold talks with his Armenian counterpart over the future of Nagorno-Karabakh.

;

;Aliyev had been considering taking part in a meeting to discuss the breakaway region – which has largely emptied out after the ;mass exodus of ethnic Armenians; – with the leaders of France, Germany, Armenia and the EU Council president, Charles Michel.

;

;Azerbaijani state media said Aliyev had wanted Turkey to be represented at the meeting with Armenia's prime minister, Nikol Pashinyan, which was scheduled for Thursday, but that France and Germany had objected.

;

;Baku felt “an anti-Azerbaijani atmosphere” had emerged among potential participants, according to reports.

;

;The Azerbaijani news outlet APA said Baku had been angered by French officials and France's decision, announced on Tuesday, to supply Yerevan with military equipment.

;
;

;;Related: ;;'It's a ghost town': UN arrives in Nagorno-Karabakh to find ethnic Armenians have fled;

;
;

;“Any format involving France is not acceptable for Azerbaijan, Baku will not participate in such a platform,” APA said, citing an unnamed Azerbaijani official.

;

;Accounts from within Nagorno-Karabakh have revealed the dramatic aftermath of the region's defeat by Azerbaijani forces in a lightning-fast military operation last month.

;

;“The city is now completely deserted. The hospitals, more than one, are not functioning,” Marco Succi, who travelled to the region this week as part of the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), said. “The medical personnel have left. The water board authorities left. The director of the morgue … the stakeholders we were working with before, have also left. This scene is quite surreal.”

;

;Succi said his ICRC team were scouring the regional capital, Stepanakert's, abandoned streets with megaphones looking for the last residents who had been unable or unwilling to leave.

;

;Succi said they found Susanna, an elderly cancer patient confined to bed, who was reportedly showing signs of malnutrition and was taken by ambulance to Armenia.

;

;A video ;published; on Wednesday by the Russian peacekeeping mission from Stepanakert similarly showed empty streets littered with debris left by former residents.

;

;International media outlets have been refused entry to Stepanakert because the area is not yet secure, Azerbaijani officials have said.

;

;Estimates of ethnic Armenians still in the Karabakh region ranged from only 50-1,000, after more than 100,000 fled in recent days, the first UN mission to the area in 30 years reported on Monday.

;

;One of the few men left was thought to be a farmer from a village near Stepanakert. Speaking in Yerevan, his daughter Ani – who asked that her second name and father's name be withheld for security reasons – told the Guardian he had decided to stay for now because he “could not leave his cattle behind”.

;

;“He told me that he does not want his cattle to die, they are his life,” Ani said.

;

;Ani last spoke to her father on Monday, when he described how fleeing neighbours had left food and other provisions that would last for three weeks. “I am not sure what he will do after that. There are no shops, no food. He is all alone there.”

;

;Western officials have urged Baku to provide the ethnic Armenians who left Nagorno-Karabakh with security guarantees that would ensure their eventual return.

;

;During a visit to Armenia on Tuesday, the French foreign ministry said that Paris was working on “a draft resolution aimed at guaranteeing a permanent international presence in Nagorno-Karabakh” that would enable Armenians “to return to their lands” in due course.

;

;But several refugees said they saw no way for them to go back to their homes, mindful of a long history of bloodshed between the two sides.

;

;“We will not return, no matter what the promises are,” said Tigran, a Nagorno-Karabakh native, in an interview from Dilijan, a town north of Yerevan where his family had been housed in a temporary shelter. “We just don't trust Azerbaijan. We don't want to live under their rule.”

;

;Azerbaijani officials have emphasised that they would guarantee “the equal rights and freedoms of everyone” in Nagorno-Karabakh, “regardless of ethnic, religious or linguistic affiliation”.

;

;But the Brussels-based International Crisis Group, pointing to the mass exodus, wrote in a ;report; this week that “the [Azerbaijani] promises made are insufficient to build trust”.

;

;“While it should be a goal of international diplomacy that the displaced can safely visit and, eventually, return to the enclave, that is likely to require a long-term effort,” the report said. “More immediately, residents of Nagorno-Karabakh will need help to start new lives in Armenia, where they may be for some time, if not permanently.”

;

;It also remains unclear whether Azerbaijan is planning to repopulate the mountainous region with its own citizens.

;

;Between 1988 and 1994, about 500,000 Azerbaijanis from Karabakh and the areas around it were expelled from their homes, according to Thomas de Waal, a Caucasus scholar and senior fellow at the Carnegie Europe thinktank.

;

;The ethnic Azeri population made up about 25% of the total population of Nagorno-Karabakh before a Russian-brokered ceasefire signed in 1994 that left Karabakh, as well as swathes of Azeri territory around, it in Armenian hands.

;

;Baku previously said it had resettled some districts in Nagorno-Karabakh that it had retaken from Armenia after six weeks of fighting in 2020, in a programme that the authorities called the “big return”.

; Wed, 04 Oct 2023 23:52:01 +0800 Trump returns to court for third day of fraud lawsuit trial following gag orderhttps://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2023/oct/04/trump-fraud-trial-gag-order-court-day-three-update

;

;Donald Trump returned to his New York civil fraud trial on Wednesday a day after ;running afoul of the judge; by denigrating a key court staffer in a social media post.

;

;The former US president and Republican front-runner in the 2024 presidential race is voluntarily taking time out from the campaign trail to attend the trial. New York attorney general Letitia James' lawsuit accuses Trump and his business of deceiving banks, insurers and others by providing financial statements that greatly exaggerated his wealth.

;

;Judge Arthur Engoron already has ruled that Trump committed fraud by inflating the values of prized assets including his Trump Tower penthouse. The ruling could, if upheld on appeal, cost Trump control of his signature skyscraper and some other properties.

;

;Trump denies any wrongdoing. With familiar rhetoric, on his way into court Wednesday, he called James “incompetent,” portrayed her as part of a broader Democratic effort to weaken his 2024 prospects, and termed the trial “a disgrace”.

;

;Trump has frequently vented in the courthouse hallway and on social media about the trial, James and Judge Arthur Engoron, also a Democrat.

;

;But after he assailed Engoron's principal law clerk on social media Tuesday, the judge imposed a limited gag order, commanding all participants in the trial not to hurl personal attacks at court staffers. The judge told Trump to delete the “disparaging, untrue and personally identifying post,” and the former president took it down.

;

;The non-jury trial concerns six claims that remained in the lawsuit after Engoron's pretrial ruling, and the trial is to determine how much Trump might owe in penalties. James is seeking $250m and a ban on Trump doing business in New York.

;

;On Wednesday, an accountant who prepared Trump's financial statements for years was to continue testifying as a witness for the state. James' lawyers are trying to show that Trump and others at his company had full control over the preparation of the statements.

;

;The accountant, Donald Bender, told the court Tuesday that the Trump Organization didn't always supply all the documents needed to produce the statements, despite attesting in letters to the accounting firm that the company had provided all financial records and hadn't “knowingly withheld” relevant data.

;

;During cross-examination, Bender acknowledged he missed a change in information about the size of Trump Tower apartment.

;

;Defense lawyer Jesus Suarez seized on that, telling Bender that Trump's company and employees were “going through hell” because “you missed it”.

;

;Bender responded: “We didn't screw it up. The Trump Organization made a mistake, and we didn't catch it.”

;

;Trump plans to testify later in the trial.

;;Wab Kinew;, the 41-year-old leader of the leftwing New Democratic party, has led the province's party since 2017. He also said the province would invest in more social housing.

;“A lot of people in the big cities, they look down on us here in Manitoba. 'Flyover country,' they said. ;

;His win Tuesday evening also cements his place in the history books as the first First Nations politician to serve as a premier. ;

;The NDP victory also hands a political lifeline to Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, who has faced stiff opposition from a wall of conservative premiers, stretching from Alberta to Prince Edward Island.

;Incumbent premier Heather Stefanson, who pledged to ;fight the federal carbon tax;, took the province's top job in the fall of 2021 and her re-election would have marked the first time a woman had been re-elected as premier in the province. ;
;

;;Related: ;; The daughter fighting to recover her mother's remains from a landfill;

;
;

;“Mr Kinew and I don't always agree on everything, but like me, I know that he loves this province and he loves the people of Manitoba,” Stefanson said. “Wab, I hope that your win tonight inspires a future generation of Indigenous youth to get involved in our democratic process – not just here in Manitoba but right across the country.”

;

;Kinew said the “people of Manitoba are good people” while his rivals attempted to drive a wedge by running on a “divisive message”. ;

;“I want to speak to the young Neechies out there,” he said, using an Ojibway word for friend. “My life became immeasurably better when I stopped making excuses and I started looking for a reason. ;

;As part of their bid to remain in power, the governing PC party had targeted Kinew's troubled past, including a criminal charge for assault and another for impaired driving. On the campaign trail, Kinew said a difficult period in his life prompted him to enter politics.

;

;“I was given a second chance in life,” said Kinew. “And I would like to think that I've made good on that opportunity.”
